[GRAMMAR]: "I could only however that evening declare to him..." (awkward phrasing)
[SYNTAX]: "I had fancied him reading it with relish, but if Corvick wasn’t satisfied how could Vereker himself be?" (awkward structure)
[SPELLING]: "I had had on my tongue’s end, for my own part, a phrase or two about the right word at the right time..." (repetition and awkward phrasing)
[PUNCTUATION]: Missing commas in complex sentences, e.g., "He had showed me Gwendolen’s photograph with the remark that she wasn’t pretty but was awfully interesting; she had published at the age of nineteen a novel in three volumes..."
[LEXICON]: "He gives me a pleasure so rare; the sense of"—he mused a little—"something or other." (awkward phrasing and incomplete thought)

[LOGIC]: Sudden shift from a literary narrative to a historical account of Bahá’u’lláh in the middle of the text.
[STRUCTURE]: The transition between the narrative about Corvick and Vereker and the historical passage is abrupt and unexplained.
[CLARITY]: The historical passage about Bahá’u’lláh is disconnected from the main narrative and lacks context.
[TRANSITION]: The shift in tone and subject between the two sections is jarring and disrupts the flow.

[GRAMMAR]: "You _haven’t_ seen it? Then you must." – Missing comma after the question.
[PUNCTUATION]: "The man has actually got _at_ you, at what _I_ always feel, you know." – Awkward phrasing and unclear use of italics.
"If the author was “only me” the thing didn’t seem quite so remarkable." – Missing comma after "me."
"She enquired, artless body, what he thought of Lady Jane’s “panegyric,” which she had read—not connecting it however with her right-hand neighbour;" – Awkward use of em dash and missing punctuation.
"Families are restricted whenever the parents have social ambitions and a standard of comfort." – Sudden shift in tone and content without transition.
[SYNTAX]: "He showed how much he was when before us all Lady Jane wanted to read something aloud." – Confusing structure.
"I did give her pleasure, I judged, but perhaps not quite so much as I had expected." – Awkward placement of "I judged."
"Hadn’t I had the effect rather of diminishing the lustre of the article than of adding to my own?" – Awkward and confusing phrasing.

"To the little fellow's home came the horror-spoken talk of Ramilies; then of Oudenarde; then of Lille--to his six-year-old ears the terrible news of Malplaquet." – Awkward and overly complex sentence structure.
[SPELLING]: "He’d take it upstairs with him and look at it on going to dress." – Ambiguous phrasing.

[LOGIC]: Sudden shift from the dinner scene to historical events about Louis XIV and François – no clear connection or transition.
The final dialogue about "stupid" is disconnected from the preceding historical section.
[STRUCTURE]: The text moves abruptly from a dinner conversation to a historical narrative, making the flow disjointed.
The text lacks a clear progression, with multiple unrelated segments.
[CLARITY]: The historical section is unclear in its relevance to the main narrative.
The purpose of the historical section is unclear and seems out of place.
[TRANSITION]: No clear transition between the dinner scene and the historical events.
